item.title: Bad Bunny Sparks a Salsa Surge With Young Dancers
item.description: His “Baile Inolvidable” has sparked a surge of interest in salsa dancing and brought in a younger generation. “It’s been positively contagious,” a teacher said.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.media:credit: Rafael Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jodi Melendez-Prokopez, left, and Marlon Mills at the Latin Mondays dance party at 5th & Mad in Manhattan.

item.title: The Soundtrack of the Doomscroll Generation? It’s Phonk.
item.description: YouTube Shorts and TikToks are often set to electronic dance music with rap roots that’s become the unconscious hum of vertical video while making its creators rich.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Prada Bianchi

item.title: The Never-Ending Trial of Tyra Banks
item.description: A new docuseries has renewed criticism of the supermodel-turned-TV mogul. It’s just one cost of her barrier-breaking career.
item.dc:creator: Maya Phillips
item.category: Reality Check: Inside America's Next Top Model (TV Program)
item.media:description: Tyra Banks sitting for an interview in “Reality Check: Inside America’s Next Top Model.”

item.title: BAFTAs Guest With Tourettes Shouts Racial Slur During Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo’s Appearance
item.description: A racist slur, shouted involuntarily while Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were presenting an award, raised questions about how the show’s host and the BBC responded.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: Nick Reiner Pleads Not Guilty in the Killing of His Parents
item.description: Mr. Reiner, 32, was charged with murdering his parents, the Hollywood director Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner, last year.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Nick Reiner waived his right to a speedy trial on Monday, two months after he was charged with first-degree murder.

item.title: ‘Survivor’ Is America
item.description: It’s our greatest game and our truest mirror. And in its tiki-torch-festooned way, it’s captured our society as an ever-changing collection of tribes.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik

item.title: Architecture Prize Responds After Tom Pritzker’s Epstein Ties Surface
item.description: A Pritzker Prize statement cited the award’s independence after Mr. Pritzker, who directs the foundation behind the award, resigned as chairman of the Hyatt Corporation.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: Nuccio DiNuzzo/Chicago Tribune/Tribune News Service via Getty Images)
item.media:description: Tom Pritzker, the director of the foundation that awards the Pritzker Prize, has said he “exercised terrible judgment in maintaining contact with” Jeffrey Epstein and his longtime companion Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.description: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: Under her leadership, Jackson said, “The most important thing is to make sure that Film Forum continues its mission.”

item.title: The ‘Scrubs’ Reboot, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The medical comedy is back for another run, and the 50th season of “Survivor” is set to begin.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Donald Faison, left, and Zach Braff in “Scrubs.”

item.title: Rose Byrne Can, and Does, Do It All
item.description: An Oscar nominee for a movie in which everything crashes down on her (literally), Byrne is shifting gears with the Broadway comedy “Fallen Angels.”
item.dc:creator: Leah Greenblatt and Sam Hellmann
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)
item.media:credit: Sam Hellmann for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Lost Boys’ on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in ‘Dracula’: Why Vampires Won’t Die
item.description: With “The Lost Boys” on Broadway and Cynthia Erivo in “Dracula” in London, our horror expert looks at how bloodsuckers sank their teeth into pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: BAFTAs Winners 2026: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Best Film, Besting ‘Sinners’
item.description: Paul Thomas Anderson’s comedy drama won six awards at the British equivalent of the Oscars. The best actor choice, however, was a surprise.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson accepts the best director award for “One Battle After Another” during the EE BAFTA Film Awards at London’s Royal Festival Hall on Feb. 22.

item.title: Political Drama ‘Yellow Letters’ Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
item.description: The film, from the director Ilker Catak, explores political repression in Turkey. Another movie set in the country, “Salvation,” took the runner-up prize.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Rogers
item.media:description: The director Ilker Catak won best film for “Yellow Letters” at the Berlin Film Festival on Saturday.

item.title: ‘The Waterfall’ Review: A Mother’s Blessing and a Daughter’s Burden
item.description: Phanésia Pharel’s wistful two-hander starring Patrice Johnson Chevannes and Natalie Paul looks at a Haitian American family and questions of legacy.
item.dc:creator: Rhoda Feng

item.title: ‘Mother Russia’ Review: A New Play That’s as Funny as It’s Smart
item.description: A strong cast stars in Lauren Yee’s new play, part of a cycle of works about the collisions between 20th-century communism and pop culture.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Steven Boyer as Dmitri and Adam Chanler-Berat as Evgeny getting a taste of capitalism in Lauren Yee’s “Mother Russia” at the Signature Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: A Wake for The Washington Post’s Book World
item.description: Literary and cultural denizens of the nation’s capital gathered on Saturday to eulogize The Post’s scuppered Book World supplement.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Dirda, a longtime book critic at The Washington Post, honors the paper’s books section, which was shuttered earlier this month amid widespread layoffs.

item.title: Jeff and Lauren Sánchez Bezos Will Be Honorary Chairs of the Met Gala
item.description: The news came tucked into the second page of a recent news release.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sánchez Bezos at a Kering Foundation gala in New York in September.

item.title: Edward Hoagland, Literary Explorer of Nature and Himself, Dies at 93
item.description: In his lyrical writings, he examined physical landscapes as well as the interior terrain of his own life — up to the blindness that overtook him in his later years.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox
item.media:description: Edward Hoagland, best known for writing about the natural world, travel and his own life, was, John Updike said, “the best essayist of my generation.”

item.title: BAFTAs 2026: The Best and Worst Moments
item.description: Alan Cumming forced fishy British snacks onto movie stars. Paddington Bear presented an award. And a racist slur and swearing.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Eleanor Stanford
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley gave the night’s most emotional and twisty speech after winning the BAFTA for best actress.

item.title: ‘The Inquisitor’ Review: Barbara Jordan Is Speaking
item.description: This whirlwind biographical documentary puts Barbara Jordan, the esteemed congresswoman and professor who died in 1996, front and center as a voice of moral authority.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold

item.title: ‘A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms’ Season 1 Finale Recap: On the Road Again
item.description: A melancholy finale sees Dunk finally treated as a proper knight, which includes a royal request to take on Egg as his proper squire.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.category: A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms (TV Program)
item.media:description: Egg (Dexter Sol Ansell) still wants to stay with Dunk, but Dunk says he is “done with princes.”

item.title: Susan Sheehan, Pulitzer-Winning Chronicler of Lives on the Margins, Dies at 88
item.description: As a journalist and author, she wrote meticulous portraits of people for The New Yorker. Her book “Is There No Place on Earth for Me?” won the Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: Is There No Place on Earth for Me? (Book)
item.media:description: Susan Sheehan in 1982 at her home in Washington.

item.title: Ethan Slater Stars as the Mime Marcel Marceau in ‘Marcel on the Train’
item.description: This bio play about Marcel Marceau, which delves into his part in the French Resistance, stars Ethan Slater (yes, that’s Boq from the “Wicked” movies).
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:description: Ethan Slater in “Marcel on the Train” at the Classic Stage Company in Manhattan.

item.title: Lisa Rinna Tells All in New Memoir, Including ‘Real Housewives’ and More
item.description: The outrageous reality TV star has written a memoir — part evolution, part exorcism. She’s more than ready to tell you why.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.category: The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Ariel Fisher for The New York Times

item.title: Tom Noonan, Actor Renowned for Onscreen Menace, Dies at 74
item.description: He played memorable screen villains, notably a psychopath in “Manhunter,” but also wrote, directed and starred in well-received plays at a theater he founded in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:description: Tom Noonan in 2015. “Anybody who saw him as an actor would know that he was the most shockingly present, immediate, in-the-moment actor,” said the actor and writer Wallace Shawn.

item.title: Willie Colón: 14 Essential Songs and Albums
item.description: The trombonist, singer, bandleader, composer and producer from the Bronx helped shape the sound of salsa.
item.dc:creator: Ed Morales
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Willie Colón onstage in 2009. The songwriter and bandleader, who died at 75, was a giant on Fania Records and beyond.

item.title: Kennedy Center Performance Canceled After Substance Poured on Ice Rink
item.description: An individual poured an unknown dark liquid onto a temporary skating rink at the Kennedy Center late Thursday night, in what the venue called a “calculated” attack.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Canadian figure-skating troupe Le Patin Libre performing at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this month.

item.title: Willie Colón, a Luminary of Salsa Music, Dies at 75
item.description: A trombonist, singer, bandleader, composer and arranger, he collaborated with Rubén Blades on “Siembra,” a 1978 release that became one of the top-selling salsa albums of all time.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Adam Bernstein
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Willie Colón performing in New York in 2009. His 1967 debut album, “El Malo,” propelled a career spanning nearly six decades.

item.title: Prosecutors Oppose Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs’s Appeal, Asserting Sentence Was Just
item.description: Mr. Combs, who is serving a 50-month sentence after his conviction on prostitution-related charges, has argued that a judge sentenced him improperly.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: In court papers on Friday, prosecutors argued that the judge who sentenced Sean Combs had rightly taken into consideration how the women had been treated while they acceded to his sexual demands.

item.title: ‘Shoresy’ Review: Heated (Brotherly) Rivalry
item.description: The Canadian comedy with creative ties to “Heated Rivalry,” in its fifth season on Hulu, has its own very different take on love among men.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: From left, Jonathan-Ismael Diaby, Andrew Antsanen, Jared Keeso and Terry Ryan play four hockey teammates who live together without women, in a scene from the fifth season of “Shoresy.”

item.title: U2, Lana Del Rey: 9 Songs We’re Talking About This Week
item.description: U2 released a seething protest song, and Lana Del Rey put out a dreamy ode to her home life.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles
item.media:description: From left: The Edge, Bono and Adam Clayton of U2. The Irish quartet surprise-released an EP this week.

item.title: Peaches on the Singer Who Is Her ‘North Star’
item.description: “There is no better performer in the world,” the electro-glam musician said. “Every song is thought out, but always with an element of spontaneity and sass.”
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times

item.title: 2026 BAFTAs: How to Watch the Ceremony
item.description: Will “One Battle After Another,” “Hamnet” or “Sinners” triumph at Britain’s equivalent of the Oscars? U.S. viewers can watch this year’s show on E!
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television

item.title: Michael Silverblatt, NPR’s ‘Bookworm’ Who Interviewed Authors, Dies at 73
item.description: His public radio show, “Bookworm,” was a literary salon of the air for 33 years, drawing guests like Joan Didion, Susan Sontag and David Foster Wallace.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.media:description: Michael Silverblatt in 1999 while hosting “Bookworm” on KCRW, a public radio station on the campus of Santa Monica College. “The purpose of the show is to help my listeners look through writers’ eyes,” he said.

item.title: Alysa Liu Trusted Her Artistry in Her Olympic Free Skate
item.description: Competition can wreck a figure skater, but Liu and other Olympians shed the pressure and delivered transcendent performances focused on artistry.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas

item.title: ‘Emily — No Prisoner Be’ Review: Kevin Puts Reimagines Dickinson
item.description: Kevin Puts’s song cycle “Emily — No Prisoner Be” was brought to life by Time for Three and Joyce DiDonato in its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall.
item.dc:creator: Oussama Zahr

item.title: 5 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: At Berlin Film Festival, the Politics Are Onscreen, Too
item.description: Some directors and stars at the Berlin Film Festival rejected a political view of cinema. But the movies there suggest that politics is broader than just activism.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.media:description: “Yellow Letters” is set in Turkey but filmed in Germany, suggesting that politics can weigh on artists’ freedom in Western democracies, too.

item.title: Five Free Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s lineup includes Spike Lee’s “Crooklyn” and other Black films that are just as rich, sharp and teeming with life.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Psycho Killer’ Review: Better the Devil You Don’t Know
item.description: A highway patrol officer travels the country to track down a hulking killing machine in this unsuccessful slasher.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: Sword Strikes Playgoer During ‘Richard III’ in Berlin
item.description: The German actor Lars Eidinger lost control of the weapon in the final scene of Shakespeare’s play.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Lars Edinger in the title role of the Schaubühne theater’s “Richard III.”

item.title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include explosive trains, a hijacked plane and stolen submarines.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels
item.media:description: Lee Lee-zen in “96 Minutes.”

item.title: South Africa Pulls Out of Venice Biennale After Gaza Artwork Furor
item.description: The country, a major center for African art, will not have an official presence at this year’s event after a legal dispute over a Gaza-focused artwork.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: The main pavilion entrance of the Venice Biennale in 2024. The event is sometimes described as the Olympics of the art world.

item.title: Watch an Ensemble Scene From ‘The Secret Agent’
item.description: Kleber Mendonça Filho narrates a sequence from his Oscar-nominated film, starring Wagner Moura.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Max Amini Is a Global Comedic Success On and Off YouTube
item.description: Max Amini has built a global following with crowd-work videos. But the Iranian American’s mix of silliness and political points about Iran land oddly.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Max Amini at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.

item.title: In the ‘Top Model’ Docuseries, Tyra Is No Longer in Control
item.description: Tyra Banks seemed almost omnipotent on her long-running reality series “America’s Next Top Model.” In a new documentary, she is merely a subject.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.category: Reality Check: Inside America's Next Top Model (TV Program)

item.title: Why a Tiny Troupe Kept Its Kennedy Center Dates
item.description: As a drove of artists ditched the center after President Trump’s takeover, an ice skating group decided it couldn’t afford to do the same.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Before its Kennedy Center premiere, Le Patin Libre released a statement reiterating its values of “artistic independence” and “resilience in the face of adversity.”

item.title: How Newly Found Footage Became ‘EPiC: Elvis Presley in Concert’
item.description: While working on a 2022 biopic of the King, Baz Luhrmann learned of unseen footage stored in a Kansas salt mine. That was the start of a winding journey.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey
item.category: Elvis: That's the Way It Is (Movie)

item.title: The NYC Theaters Where the Oscar Nominees Are Playing
item.description: If you want to catch them all, there are many places to see them in the five boroughs.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg and Danielle Dowling

item.title: ‘EPiC: Elvis Presley in Concert’ Review
item.description: Newly found footage makes for a fun and revealing concert movie from the director Baz Luhrmann.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: How a New Yorker Put Poetry on the London Underground
item.description: Judith Chernaik’s idea to feature verse in subway cars has transformed the morning commutes of millions worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Secret Agent’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The director Kleber Mendonça Filho narrates an ensemble sequence from his film, which is nominated for best picture.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy

item.title: Stephen Colbert Balks at Trump’s Board of Peace
item.description: “The Late Show” host called the group “kind of like the U.N., except instead of passing binding resolutions, you pass a greasy bag of money to Donald Trump.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Emotional Rescue
item.description: Robby and Langdon have an awkward encounter in an elevator. Dana struggles to keep it together in a difficult case involving sexual assault.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Langdon and Robby (Patrick Ball, left, and Noah Wyle) were finally forced to air things out ... somewhat, and under less-than-ideal circumstances.

item.title: Eric Dane, McSteamy on ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ Dies at 53 After Battling ALS
item.description: His breakout role came in 2006 as the handsome Dr. Mark Sloan, nicknamed McSteamy, the head of plastic surgery at a Seattle hospital. He died 10 months after announcing his A.L.S. diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Eric Dane revealed in April 2025 that he had A.L.S.

item.title: Cees Nooteboom, Voyaging Author of Enigmatic Novels, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific Dutch writer of fiction, poetry and travel books, he was often mentioned as a potential recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Cees Nooteboom in 2015. The author of dozens of works of fiction, poetry, journalism and travel writing, he was perennially mentioned as a possible recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.

item.title: Billy Steinberg, Hitmaking Lyricist of Madonna’s ‘Like a Virgin,’ Dies at 75
item.description: He co-wrote five pop-rock songs that soared to No. 1 in the 1980s and shared in a Grammy for producing Celine Dion’s 1996 album “Falling Into You.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Larry Busacca/Getty Images for Songwriters Hall of Fame
item.media:description: Billy Steinberg performing at the Songwriters Hall of Fame ceremony in 2011. With fellow inductee Tom Kelly, Mr. Steinberg wrote hundreds of songs, including “True Colors,” a hit for Cyndi Lauper.

item.title: ‘Portobello’ Review: When Italy’s Biggest TV Star Was Canceled
item.description: An HBO Max series tells the surreal true story of Enzo Tortora, brought down overnight by false accusations of being a member of the mob.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: Fabrizio Gifuni as the unjustly disgraced Italian TV star Enzo Tortora, who in the 1970s and ’80s hosted an enormously popular variety show called “Portobello.”

item.title: 12 Steps and Cups of Coffee: Sobriety Has Its Moment Onstage
item.description: Plays about addiction are filling Manhattan stages this month, depicting very different places on the recovery spectrum, from harrowing to serene.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: From left, Caroline Aaron, Noah Galvin, Peter Maloney and Chip Zien in “The Reservoir” at Atlantic Theater Company in Manhattan.

item.title: Met Opera Announces 2026-27 Season: What We Want to See
item.description: Among the highlights are the world premiere of an adaptation of “Lincoln in the Bardo,” and classics like “Macbeth” and “Jenufa.”

item.title: José van Dam, Suave and Riveting Opera Star, Dies at 85
item.description: One of the most esteemed singers of his era, he had a wide repertoire that included Mozart, Wagner and the title role in Messiaen’s epic “St. François d’Assise.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Kandell
item.media:description: José van Dam in 1987 as the title character in Wagner’s “The Flying Dutchman” at the San Francisco Opera.
